header.name: chaos/preprocessor/repetition/repeat.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that repeats a user-specified target a specified number of times.

macro.abstract: The macro repeats its second argument the number of times specified by its first argument.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of repeating the target count times. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code:
macro(s, 0, data) macro(s, 1, data) ... macro(s, count - 1, data)

The target is invoked repeatedly (from 0 to count - 1) with the current (s), the current repetition (n), and, if it exists, the auxiliary data (data or __VA_ARGS__). This target may expand to a in terms of (s). This allows the target to recurse on itself if necessary.

In C99, it is possible to omit the auxiliary data argument altogether. This is different than passing "nothing" as the auxiliary data.
( (10, MACRO,) // #1 (10, MACRO) // #2 )
The first line passes "nothing" as the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, 0,) The second line omits the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, 0) The fundamental difference is that, in the first line, the auxiliary data is empty (which might have a valid meaning as data), but, in the second line, there is no auxiliary data. Hence, the algorithm is overloaded on a .
Invocations of the target are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with (s), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

Ignoring the complexity of macro (which is invoked exactly count times), the running time of can be described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θ(n+1), where n is count.
